dialogues.text: Really? That’s a coincidence. My top schools where I want to apply are Oxford and the Sorbonne. But my safety is Harvard.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: (smiles) That’s very ambitious.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Thank you.  a MISS CROSS What are you going to major in?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Well. I haven‘t decided for sure. But probably a double-major in Mathematics and Pre-Med. What was your major?

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Latin-American studies.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Ah. That‘s interesting. Did you hear they're not going to teach Latin here anymore?

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: This is more like Central America.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (pause) Sure. Central America and what-not. But moving on: they're going to cancel Latin. They have to make room for Japanese.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Really? That's too bad. All the Romance Languages come from Latin.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: They do, don't they? (pause) Like French, probably. She nods. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Nihilo sanctum estne?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: That's Latin, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: What does it mean?

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Is nothing sacred?  Long pause. Looking right at her.

dialogues.speaker: . MAX
dialogues.text: Sic transit gloria. Glory fades. I'm Max Fischer. Max slides down the bench and puts out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Hi. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LUNCHROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: A crowd of MIDDLE SCHOOLERS has gathered around Max. He i holding a clipboard. One of the kids finishes signing a p of paper on it.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Good. Now you. (points to the next kid) Sign here. The kid signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long list of signatures. Many of them are written in li kids' handwriting. Some are neater. Across the top it say PETITION. This is written in calligraphy. cuT TO: The administration conference room. TEN TEACHERS sit in chairs around a long table. Max stands before them finish a speech. The petition is tacked-up on the wall behind hi

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: In summation I have only one ques- tion: is Latin dead? Nisilum sacnus (pause, looks at his notecards) estne? Only you can say. Thank you for your time. Applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks in part to the efforts of 10th class member Max Fischer, Latin will now be a required course for grades 7 through

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: 22 Max and a bunch of other kids are reading this announceme on the bulletin board. Max is smiling S@renely. The other are cursing and locking at Max with angry faces. Magnus Buchan is one of them. He has a strong Scottish accent.

dialogues.speaker: MAGNUS
dialogues.text: Bugger off, Fischer. Ya bleedin’ little bollocks.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Is that Latin? Not bad, Buchan. Maybe you'll place out of your firsce year.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GYM. DAY
dialogues.text: Mr. Blume's son Ronny is in a wrestling match. He's get h opponent in a choke hold and is slowly strangling him. Mr. Blume looks on distastefully from the stands. Max is his side.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: Tell me something, Max. What do you make of this game?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (philosophically) ’ Well. I don't mean to be critical. But, in my opinion, it's not a very elegant sport.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: I think you're right.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Thank you. Mr. Blume shakes his head and stares across the gym. Ronn crushing his opponent's face into the mat with his fist.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: Never in my wildest imaginations did I dream I would have sons like these. (sighs) What does your dad do, Max? (frankly) He's a neurosurgeon.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: is he?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Yeah. Over at St. Joseph's. Personally. I could never see myself cutting open somebody's brain. But he enjoys it. (pause) You were in Vietnam, weren't you?

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Were you in the shit?

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: Yeah. I was in the shit.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (wistfully) We lost that one, didn't we? Mr. Blume nods.

dialogues.speaker: WRESTLER
dialogues.text: See you Sunday, Mr. Blume. A stocky WRESTLER with an icepack on his arm walks by on way to the showers. Mr. Blume nods to him without looking

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: What's Sunday? Oh. That's right. The twins’ birthday party. Ronny flips his opponent on the mat and flattens him with body. Donny screams encouragement. Mr. Blume looks to Max

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: You want to come?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (regretfully) I'd love to. Except I already have a previous obligation. But thanks for the invitation. Max smiles very sincerely. Mr. Blume looks at him for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: Come work for me.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: What?  24

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: Come work for me.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (stiffens) I may not be rich, Mr. Blume. And my father may only be a doctor. But we manage.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: Well, I didn't mean it like that. I just thought it might be nice to have you in the company.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I appreciate the offer. But I've got everything I need right here at Rushmore. As long as they don't kick me out. Besides, it wouldn’t be fair.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Blume. Nice talking with you. Max pulls off his blazer. He is wearing wrestling tights underneath. Mr. Blume looks suprised.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: You're on the team?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I'm an alternate. Max heads out to the mat, pulling on his headgear. Mr. Bl calls after him:

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: What wouldn’t be fair, Max?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (looking back over his shoulder) We'd make too much money working on the same team. Mr. Blume smiles faintly. He watches as Max begins his ma Max is clearly outclassed and gets quickly pinned.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: 2s Miss Cross is shepherding her class into her classroom. T are singing a song as they walk down the corridor. Across hall a fourth gr. teacher, MRS. GUGGENHEIM, comes out of her classroom. She is a handsome woman in her late sixtie with black and silver hair.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Hello, Mrs. Guggenheim.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GUGGENHEIM
dialogues.text: Hi, Rosemary. How’s everything shaping up?

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Fine, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GUGGENHEIM
dialogues.text: You find a place?

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Well, I'm just staying over at Edward's parents' house for now. They're out of town.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GUGGENHEIM
dialogues.text: Oh. That‘s good. (pause) Edward was one of my students, you know. I was awfully sorry to hear about thar. Miss Cross smiles and nods. Silence. Miss Cross points to photograph in a collage on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: I think I met that boy yesterd. Mrs. Guggenheim looks at the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a black and white of Max in fifth grade singing a showtune. His arms are opened wide and he has a top hat i one hand and a cane in the other.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GUGGENHEIM
dialogues.text: That's Max Fischer. He’s one of my favorites.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COUNTRY CLUB. DAY
dialogues.text: Ronny and Donny set upon a pile of birthday presents at a table by the pool. They are surrounded by kids in swimsui  26 Mr. Blume sits alone at the next table drinking a whiskey front of the demolished birthday cake. He has a tattoo on shoulder that says Semper Fi. There is a bucket of golf b in front of him and he absentiy tosses them into the pool at a time. He looks over at MRS. BLUME. She has red hair just like t twins. She is flirting with a pretty-boy TENNIS PRO. She lecks back to Mr. Blume coldly. Mr. Blume gets up and walks around the pool. He pauses to shake hands with a BIG MAN drinking a glass of scotch. Th big man gives Mr. Blume a sudden shove toward the pool, b hangs onto him so he doesn't fall in. The big man laughs. Mr. Blume climbs up the ladder to the high dive. He sets his cocktail. He slips and falls and bangs his knee hard the edge of the board. He gets up quickly. There is a had on his knee and he is bleeding. He looks out at the birth party down below. People begin to notice him up there. He sprints down the board, bounces once as high as he can and sails out long through the air. He tucks into a canonball. He nails the water with a huge splash. Mrs. Blume gets up with a bitter look on her face and hea for the ladies room. Kids gather at the edge of the pool to look down at Mr. B playing dead at the bottom with golf balls all around him little boy in a Speedo swims underwater to examine Mr. Bl Their eyes meet. The boy turns and swims away.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLASSROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Miss Cross's classroom. The walls are lined with fishtank that glow blue and make bubbling sounds. There are maps a pictures everywhere. A model of a 747 hangs from the ceil A record player plays the Vienna Boys’ Choir at a low vol There is only one KID in the room. He is taking a test. M Cross sits at her desk grading papers. Max cracks open the door.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Miss Cross? Miss Cross and the kid look back at Max. Miss Cross holds finger to her lips and gets up. As she walks past the kid puts her hand on the top of his head. She goes to Max at door. She whispers:  27

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: He's taking a make-up test.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: These guys have tests?

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I thought they just did coloring and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Oh, no. They're good readers.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I'm Max Fischer. We met the other day.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: I know who you are. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Fine, thank you. Max just stands there. MISS CROSS . You want to help me feed the fish?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Yes, please. Max follows her from tank to tank as she shakes out fish food. They continue to whisper to each other:

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I thought I would just let you know, as per our conversation the other day --

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Latin?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Right. The Romance Languages. I gave a little speech --

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: I heard about this.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. I understand you made a very convincing argument.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I thought you'd be pleased to hear they're going to continue the Latin program. She looks at Max. She sets down the fish food and shakes hand.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: I'm very impressed.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. Max picks up the can of fish food and shakes some into on the aquariums.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: You need an assistant?

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: (smiles) Do we get to have assistants around here?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I doubt it. I'm on scholarship, though. Academic scholarship. So sometimes I get to do odd jobs. (pause) How did you decide to teach at Rushmore?

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: My husband went here. Max drops the can of fish food into the tank. He quickly fishes it out. He picks some little bits of fish food out the water and throws them away. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I didn’t know you were married.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Well, he’s dead now. So I’m not, actually.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: When did he die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last year. Max nods. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: My mother’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Oh. I’m sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: She died when I was seven. (raising an eyebrow) So we both have dead people in our families. They look at each other for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Now what's going on in here? Max kneels down and looks into one of the fishtanks. Ther are a hundred little seahorses swimming around in it.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Those were just born. A look of wonder comes across Max's face. He stares into blue water.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: You really love fish, don’t you? Miss Cross nods. Max puts his fingers to the glass.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: How much do these cost?

dialogues.speaker: INT. BLUME INTERNATIONAL CONCRETE. DAY
dialogues.text: Mr. Blume's office. He is talking on the telephone. Max s in a chair across from him.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: I don't want any alloys. I want steel. (pause) I don't give a rat's ass if he did. (pause) Steel, Harry. He hangs up.  30

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: Yoy change your mind? You want the job? ve No. But I've got an idea. And I need some money. Mr. Blume's secretary buzzes him on the speakerphone.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Mr. Blume, they're ready for you in Hydraulics.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: Come with me. Let's hear your idea.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FACTORY. DAY
dialogues.text: Max, Mr. Blume, and a big foreman named ERNIE race across factory in a souped-up golf cart. They're squeezed togeth with Max in the middle.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Rushmore deserves an aquarium. A first class aquarium where scientists can lecture, and students can study marine life in their natural --

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: I don't know. What do you think, Ernie?

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: (skeptical) An aquarium?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: A huge aquarium. An entire building.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: What kind of fish?

dialogues.speaker: INT. FACTORY. DAY
dialogues.text: Mr. Blume and Max, wearing hard hats, stand on a scaffold overlooking a huge vat of bubbling concrete.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (shouting) Electric eels. Baracudas. Stingrays. Hammerheads. Piranhas.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: Piranhas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Piranhas. I talked to aman in South America.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: Really. So you might have piranhas.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: We will have piranhas.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MR. BLUME'S OFFICE OFFICE. DAY
dialogues.text: Back in Mr. Blume’s office. They're seated as before. Max still wearing his hardhat. Leng pause.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: What does Guggenheim say?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Nothing. I felt I should go to you first.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Because at this moment I feel our best strategy is to keep a low pro- file. The more preparation I can do, the stronger our case will be when we go to the administration.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: How much do you want?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: $5000 for the initial plans. Max holds Mr. Blume‘'s gaze. Mr. Blume picks up a pen.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: I'll give you $2500. Max nods. Mr. Blume writes out a check, tears it off, and hands it to Max. Max sticks it in his pocket like it is a five dollar bill.

Max watches a Jaques Cousteau film on i6mm in an empty classroom. Dirk runs the projector. Max visits a marine research facility and talks with a SCIENTIST. Max holds up a fish at the edge of a pool. Max walks with a young ARCHITECT among the trees between gym and the baseball diamond. They look at some blueprint Max pulls up third base and slides it over a few feet. Max points to some beautiful fish in an aqaurium in a pet shop. The pet shop OWNER reaches in with a little net. Max pokes his head into Miss Cross' classroom. He holds u two plastic baggies full of water with tropical fish swim around inside them. Kids gather all around them as they put the new fish into aquariums. Max smiles mysteriously.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: You need any help grading papers or anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The title is Young Ben Franklin. Miss Cross writes Magnificent! Keep up the good work! and draws two stars across the top of the page with a red pen.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MISS CROSS' CLASSROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Max is staring at Miss Cross in a trance from a desk oppo hers in the empty classroom. She looks up at him. He continues to stare at her as if she were a statue. Miss Cross rubs her eyes and sighs. She sets down her red pen. She looks back to Max. He is still staring at her.  33

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Max? Max looks quickly down to his papers.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Uh-huh?

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Has it ever crossed your mind that you're way too young for me? Max looks up. Miss Cross smiles faintly. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: It‘s crossed my mind that you might consider that a possibility, yes.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Not to mention that you're a student --

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: And you're a teacher. And never the twain shall meet. I know. I'm not trying to pressure you into any- thing, Miss Cross. I'm surprised you brought it up so blunrly.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: I just want to make sure --

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: We've become friends, haven't we?

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Good. That's all that matters to me. Max thinks for a second, then presses on:

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: And the truth is neither one of us has the slightest idea where this relationship is going. We can‘t pre- dict the future.  34

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: We don't have a relationship, Max.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: But we're friends.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Yes. And that's all we're going to be.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: That's what I meant by relationship. You want me to grab a dictionary?

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: I just want to make sure we under- stand each other.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I understand. You're not attracted to me. C'est la vie. I'ma big hoy.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Max. You're fifteen. Attraction doesn't enter into it.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: If you say so. All I'm getting at is I've never met anyone like you. Take that for whatever it's worth. She thinks about this for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: I think I can safely say I've never met anyone like you (pause) in a long time, either.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: You haven't, have you? Miss Cross shakes her head. Max says quietly:

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: You want to shake hands? She puts out her hand and they shake hands across the des But they don't let.go. They just look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I'm glad we had this conversation.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: 35 Me, too. a They finally let igo of each other's hands. Miss Cross lo away. She's not exactly sure what they just decided.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Bye the bye. Are you free Thursday night?

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: Free for what?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Dinner. She looks at Max strangely.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: We're getting a group together after the play.

dialogues.text: A very realistic set for a New York tenement apartment. Four men sit at a table. Three wear dark suits: O'REILLY, BURNUM, and FIELDS. One has long hair, a beard, leather pants, and a big silver crucifix around his neck. This is Frank Serpico. They are all played by high schoolers.

dialogues.text: I can‘t wear a wire! They're feeling me up every day!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (walking off) I‘ve heard that one before. I got to go put a dime in the meter.

dialogues.text: What happened to the cannoli line? Max follows Frank as Frank walks quickly toward the dress rooms .

dialogues.text: You're supposed to say, Forget about it, Sanchez --

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (very angry) I made a mistake, all right? It didn't make any difference, anyway .

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm letting it go. But don't  tell me it doesn’t matter, Every line matters.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (yelling) Get off my back!

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Don't fuek with my play! Frank turns around and punches Max in the nose. Max takes swing and misses and they wrestle around as people try to break it up.

dialogues.speaker: INT. AUDITORIUM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The whole cast is onstage bowing as the audience applauds Some of the actors motion to the wings. Max walks out onto the stage. He's got a bloody kleenex i each nostril. He waves to the audience. The applause roar

dialogues.speaker: INT. BACKSTAGE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The crowded dressing rooms. Actors are taking off their m up. Max is drinking a champagne cocktail and talking with father and an elderly WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I thought the acting tonight ‘was excellent.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: It was better in rehearsals. (to his father) I'll catch up with you later, Dad. I’ve got a dinner to go to.

dialogues.speaker: MR. FISCHER
dialogues.text: (interested) Oh, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Yeah. (pause) Cast and crew only. Mr. Fischer feels left out but tries not to show it.

dialogues.speaker: MR. FISCHER
dialogues.text: OK. Well, have a good time.  38 Miss Cross walks over to Max through the crowd. Her frien the medical student follows behind her. Max’s expression ~~ polite but inscrutable.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: That was great, Max.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I'm so glad you could come.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: I want you to meet a friend of mine. John Coats. Max Fischer.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (not looking at him) Who's this guy?

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: ‘ (pause) : John. Max looks at John. John smiles. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I really liked your play, man. It was really cool. Max nods. He drinks a long sip of his champagne cocktail.

dialogues.speaker: MISS CROSS
dialogues.text: What happened to your nose?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I got punched in the face. (to John) What's your excuse? Mr. Blume comes over to them.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLUME
dialogues.text: Am I going to get to meet your dad tonight, Max?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
